problem.tex: Find the Laurent series of the function $f(z)=\frac{z-1}{(z-2)(z-3)}$ for the annulus $2<|z|<3$.

solution.tex: Recall that, for $|r|<1$, \[\sum_{n=0}^\infty r^n=\frac{1}{1-r}.\] If $2<|z|$ then $\left|\frac{2}{z}\right|<1$, so \[\sum_{n=0}^\infty\left(\frac{2}{z}\right)^n=\frac{1}{1-\frac{2}{z}}=\frac{z}{z-2}.\] If $|z|<3$ then $\left|\frac{z}{3}\right|<1$, so \[\sum_{n=0}^\infty\left(\frac{z}{3}\right)^n=\frac{1}{1-\frac{z}{3}}=\frac{-3}{z-3}.\] Now \[\frac{z-1}{(z-2)(z-3)}=(z-1)\frac{1}{-3z}\frac{-3z}{(z-2)(z-3)}=\frac{z-1}{-3z}\left(\sum_{n=0}^\infty\left(\frac{2}{z}\right)^n\right)\left(\sum_{n=0}^\infty\left(\frac{z}{3}\right)^n\right).\] Further simplification is possible, but unnecessary. We have a Laurent expansion which converges in the correct region. Note that partial fractions would have ended with a sum instead of a product here.
